Assaf Arkin wrote:
> On Tue, Oct 21, 2008 at 2:47 PM, Bill de hOra <bill@... 
> <mailto:bill@...>> wrote:
> 
>     Stefan Tilkov wrote:
>      >
>      >
>      > On 16.10.2008, at 22:03, Bill de hOra wrote:
>      >
>      >  > Stefan Tilkov wrote:
>      >  > >
>      >  > > I POST the URI itself (sans XML) to the collection and
>     return a 200.
>      >  >
>      >  > How do you remove it?
>      >  >
>      >  > Bill
>      >  >
>      >
>      > Good question with no generic answer. The few occasions I did this,
>      > stuff was removed through some backend logic (i.e. not via the
>     RESTful
>      > interface) or never removed at all.
> 
>     It's worth digging into. This is an area (along with partial updates)
>     where I'm prone to sympathizing with the RPC crowd*, as in, it tends to
>     require a pattern or an idiom. On that basis you can argue that there is
>     a capability than people need - the ability to relate resources. How to
>     do this is not evident when I look at REST.
> 
> 
> Let's say I want to label this email "interesting".  My Web-based email 
> client has actions for creating these associations (email and label), 
> deleting existing associations, and links to retrieve the associated 
> collection (i.e. all emails belonging to a label).
> 
> I would post the id, not the URL, of the resource that I'm enlisting 
> with the collection, and likewise post to remove it, using different 
> target URLs for these two actions.  That's a pattern and it restricts 
> itself to REST.  

That's two remote procedure calls, no? I have used that pattern for 
tagging. An alternative is to state the relationship using a content 
type. In OO terms, this is the 'marriage problem' - namely where does 
the act of marriage belong in an object oriented system?


> So I'm thinking what's missing is not the way to do it, 
> but the way to indicate that a bunch of actions and links returned from 
> a resource signify "add/remove from designated collection".
> 
> Add semantics to the content?  Service description language?

At the level of architecture it makes no odds - REST has nothing useful 
to say. I suspect this is why TBL champions technology like RDF, which 
formally defines resource relationships. [REST had nothing useful to say 
about iterators either but that didn't stop us defining the incredibly 
useful RSS/Atom, and later on, layering AtomPub onto HTTP.]

Bill
